items.content_html: I decided to provide those Nixon photos my Dad took to the Columbus Metropolitan Library for their digital archives. They’re here in the “Columbus Memory” collection. I’m sure he would’ve approved, and selfishly, it makes me feel good to contribute a little bit of his life to the city he loved.
items.content_text: I decided to provide [those Nixon photos my Dad took](/2025/02/02/clicking-through-the-columbus-librarys/) to the Columbus Metropolitan Library for their digital archives. They're [here](https://cdm16802.contentdm.oclc.org/digital/collection/memory/id/162916/rec/2) in the "Columbus Memory" collection. I'm sure he would've approved, and selfishly, it makes me feel good to contribute a little bit of his life to the city he loved.

items.content_html: Checked a very longstanding item off of my to-do list today: photographed the original Port Columbus airport terminal constructed in 1929.
items.content_text: Checked a _very_ longstanding item off of my to-do list today: photographed the original Port Columbus airport terminal constructed in 1929.

items.content_html: Hot tub, dog walk, grocery store, another grocery store, another dog walk. Yep, it’s Groundhog Day alright.
items.content_text: Hot tub, dog walk, grocery store, another grocery store, another dog walk. Yep, it's Groundhog Day alright.

items.content_html: Clicking through the Columbus library’s archives lately has inspired me to share some of my own collection. It’s always bothered me that pictures get trapped inside albums and never seen again. Some pics of local interest: a radio station promotion in 1991 and a Nixon speech my Dad attended in 1970.
items.content_text: Clicking through the Columbus library's archives lately has inspired me to share some of my own collection. It's always bothered me that pictures get trapped inside albums and never seen again. Some pics of local interest: a [radio station promotion](https://mike.dunn.blog/26258 "Photos of a WNCI promotion for Easter Seals.") in 1991 and a [Nixon speech](https://mike.dunn.blog/26508 "President Richard Nixon speaking at the Ohio Statehouse in 1970.") my Dad attended in 1970.

items.content_html: I’m sitting in Columbus and using T-Mobile, which assigns me an IP address geolocated in Nashville, so when I load my WordPress site, Cloudflare pulls it from a cache in a data center in Atlanta, which in turn pulls from an origin server in – wait for it – Columbus. ðŸ¤ª
items.content_text: I'm sitting in Columbus and using T-Mobile, which assigns me an IP address geolocated in Nashville, so when I load my WordPress site, Cloudflare pulls it from a cache in a data center in Atlanta, which in turn pulls from an origin server in -- wait for it -- Columbus. ðŸ¤ª

items.content_html: Spent most of the past two days diagnosing why email from WordPress suddenly stopped. Very long story short, OpenSSL’s cert verification while connecting to Amazon SES was quietly failing. Still not sure how it broke, and the fix is an unsatisfying workaround, but it’s working now. Commence weekend.
items.content_text: Spent most of the past two days diagnosing why email from WordPress suddenly stopped. _Very_ long story short, OpenSSL's cert verification while connecting to Amazon SES was quietly failing. Still not sure how it broke, and the fix is an [unsatisfying workaround](https://medium.com/@erlandmuchasaj/starttls-stream-socket-enable-crypto-error-de7dea4e1a), but it's working now. Commence weekend.

items.content_html: My neighborhood was featured in one of those HGTV-style “which house did this couple pick?” articles in the New York Times: “Buying a House Sight-Unseen Is Hard Enough. They Did It From 10 Time Zones Away." Go Clintonville!
items.content_text: My neighborhood was featured in one of those HGTV-style "which house did this couple pick?" articles in the New York Times: ["Buying a House Sight-Unseen Is Hard Enough. They Did It From 10 Time Zones Away."](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/01/30/realestate/columbus-ohio-homes-sale.html) Go Clintonville!

items.content_html: Went crazy this morning registering a bunch of old domain names I’ve used at various times over the past 25 years. Fortunately they were all available and very inexpensive. Now the question is, why did I just do that?

items.content_html: Despite growing up when film photography was really the only photography, Iâ€™ve never shot with film this fast. Should be a fun experiment!
items.content_text: Despite growing up when film photography was really the _only_ photography, Iâ€™ve never shot with film this fast. Should be a fun experiment!

items.content_html: Lately I’ve been finding myself getting lost in old photographs in the Columbus Metropolitan Library’s vast digital collection. There are historic moments like Lincoln’s funeral train moving through town and odd ones like Jayne Mansfield’s plane making a brief stop here. It truly is time traveling.
items.content_text: Lately I've been finding myself getting lost in old photographs in the Columbus Metropolitan Library's vast [digital collection](https://www.columbuslibrary.org/myhistory). There are historic moments like Lincoln's [funeral train moving through town](https://digital-collections.columbuslibrary.org/digital/collection/ohio/id/12727/rec/23) and odd ones like Jayne Mansfield's plane [making a brief stop here](https://digital-collections.columbuslibrary.org/digital/collection/ohio/id/18874/rec/1). It truly is time traveling.

items.content_html: Stumbled on this post about WordPress disabling attachment pages. For blogs, thumbs up! The media inside a blog post is the attachment, so why did it also need a separate page with no context? And, WordPress has never consistently attached posts in the media library anyway.
items.content_text: Stumbled on [this post](https://make.wordpress.org/core/2023/10/16/changes-to-attachment-pages/) about WordPress disabling attachment pages. For blogs, thumbs up! The media inside a blog post _is_ the attachment, so why did it also need a separate page with no context? And, WordPress has never consistently attached posts in the media library anyway.

items.content_html: Signed up for Threads against my better judgement. Half of the default feed is pictures of scantily clad teenage girls doing duck face selfies and the other half is people (bots?) posting things like “react this I add you”. I feel like I need a shower.

items.title: Coco
items.content_html: A year ago today, this little girl left us. She was always bursting with personality and energy (and demands), and our house feels much emptier without her. (May misses her too, although she won’t admit it.)
items.content_text: A year ago today, this little girl left us. She was always bursting with personality and energy (and demands), and our house feels much emptier without her. ([May](https://mikedunn.blog/2025/01/09/celebrating-gotcha-day-by-doing) misses her too, although she won't admit it.)

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Discovery of the Titanic by Robert D. Ballard ðŸ“š An interesting firsthand account of the 1985 discovery (a major media event those of us of a certain age remember well), and a reminder of what an accomplishment it was (for better or worse, depending on your take on subsequent visitors).
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Discovery of the Titanic](https://micro.blog/books/9780446513852) by Robert D. items.content_html: Stopped by the former Wendy’s restaurant here in Columbus that briefly served as “Holy Chicken” for Morgan Spurlock’s 2017 sequel to Super Size Me. Over seven years later, it’s still looking for a tenant (and still has the green paint he added to give it a deceptively “healthy” look).
items.content_text: Stopped by the former Wendy's restaurant here in Columbus that briefly served as "Holy Chicken" for Morgan Spurlock's [2017 sequel to _Super Size Me_](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dSyicDf9UvI). Over seven years later, it's still looking for a tenant (and still has the green paint he added to give it a deceptively "healthy" look).

items.content_html: In today’s Columbus Dispatch: “From arsenal to education: Fort Hayes students work to preserve military complex’s history”. Always love hearing about the activities of students at my high school alma mater (which was an active military facility from the Civil War until 2009). Love visiting, too!
items.content_text: In today's Columbus Dispatch: ["From arsenal to education: Fort Hayes students work to preserve military complex's history"](https://www.dispatch.com/story/news/education/2025/01/06/fort-hayes-students-preserving-history-of-the-fort-turned-school/76924542007). Always love hearing about the activities of students at my high school alma mater (which was an active military facility from the Civil War until 2009). Love [visiting](https://old.mikedunn.blog/18067), too!

items.content_html: The amount of panic these days over a few inches of snow is just hilarious to me. No ice, no subzero wind chills, just a few inches of snow. School and business closings galore.
items.content_text: The amount of panic these days over a few inches of snow is just hilarious to me. No ice, no subzero wind chills, just a few inches of snow. School and business closings galore.

items.content_html: Finished reading: Letterman by Jason Zinoman ðŸ“š A bit of a slog to get through this. A very detailed deconstruction of Letterman’s career, although it went a little too deep into the jockeying and infighting among his writing staff. It did remind me of something I loved about Late Night: Dave flinging blue cards through the fake window behind him.
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Letterman](https://micro.blog/books/9780062377241) by Jason Zinoman ðŸ“š A bit of a slog to get through this. A very detailed deconstruction of Letterman's career, although it went a little too deep into the jockeying and infighting among his writing staff. It did remind me of something I loved about _Late Night_: Dave [flinging blue cards through the fake window behind him](https://tenor.com/view/dave-letterman-viewer-mail-flip-a-card-letter-flipping-light-night-with-gif-26020347).

items.content_html: I remember watching the first live episode of the â€˜90s sitcom Roc, but I had forgotten that they did the entire second season live, too. The cast is so good, itâ€™s hard to believe those episodes were all done in one take.
